channel.title: BBC News - UK Politics

item.title: MPs to vote on health and social care tax rise
item.description: Boris Johnson says plan to raise National Insurance by 1.25 percentage points is "reasonable and fair".

item.title: Social care changes at-a-glance
item.description: The government's promising to restrict costs for families - but what is changing and how will it be funded?

item.title: Triple lock pension pledge suspended for one year
item.description: It follows government concern that a big rise in earnings would have meant pensions increasing by 8%.

item.title: Wales' MPs could be cut by eight as major changes published
item.description: The Welsh secretary is among the MPs seeing their seats redrawn in the proposals.

item.title: Chancellor Rishi Sunak announces date of Autumn Budget
item.description: It comes as the Treasury asks government departments to identify 5% of "savings and efficiencies".

item.title: Scottish government to restart work on case for independence
item.description: The Scottish government had paused its indyref2 plans because of the Covid pandemic.

item.title: Covid: No plans for October lockdown, says government
item.description: Officials deny a newspaper report saying new rules could come in around England's half-term holiday.

item.title: NI Protocol: Further delays for Irish Sea border checks
item.description: The UK's Brexit minister says the move will "provide space for further discussions" with the EU.

item.title: Afghanistan: PM pledges not to abandon UK allies left behind
item.description: Boris Johnson promises help for them to leave safely - but is accused of not showing leadership.

item.title: Nicola Sturgeon to set out plans for Holyrood year ahead
item.description: Scotland's first minister will announce her "programme for government" for the coming year at Holyrood.

item.title: Marcus Rashford says child food poverty 'devastatingly' worse
item.description: The footballer urges people to write to their MP as a survey indicates food poverty is worsening.

item.title: NHS to get Â£5.4bn extra to deal with Covid backlog
item.description: Boris Johnson says the money will "go straight to the front line" in England over the next six months.

item.title: Commons Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle: I've received death threats
item.description: Sir Lindsay Hoyle urges fellow MPs to be "careful" but not to be deterred from doing their job.

item.title: Pensions: What is the triple lock and why has it been 'suspended'?
item.description: The government has changed a policy which determines the annual rise in the state pension.

item.title: Afghanistan: Minister apologises over 'inaccurate' veteran suicide claim
item.description: James Heappey corrects himself after mistakenly saying a British Afghan veteran had taken their own life.

item.title: Covid-19: Vaccine passports to start in England this month
item.description: The scheme for nightclubs and other venues from the end of September aims to ensure they stay open.

item.title: Nadia Whittome: MP back at work after leave of absence with PTSD
item.description: Nadia Whittome, Labour MP for Nottingham East, says she is making a "good recovery".

item.title: Young people's mental health services 'in crisis', MPs warn
item.description: Waiting times at the Sussex Partnership NHS Trust have missed targets since 2019, board papers show.

item.title: Frozen eggs and sperm storage limit increased to 55 years
item.description: The health secretary says it "will help turn off the ticking clock in the back of people's minds".

item.title: Lord Frost warns of 'cold mistrust' over NI Protocol
item.description: The UK Brexit minister has called again on the EU to accept "substantial change" to arrangements.

item.title: MPs told to smarten up their clothing ahead of Commons return
item.description: Jeans and chinos are banned in a toughening of post-Zoom Commons rules set by the Speaker.

item.title: Brexit: 'Proportionate' response needed for Northern Ireland Protocol talks
item.description: An open letter from business leaders and academics calls for solutions to post-Brexit tensions.

item.title: Afghanistan: Senior Conservative attacks top official's holiday during crisis
item.description: Tom Tugendhat tells BBC's Political Thinking it was like a "general not coming back" for a battle.

item.title: Government communications are failing, says ex-No 10 adviser
item.description: The PM's ex-adviser says inexperienced staff and leaks damaged the government's Covid response.

item.title: Afghanistan: Leaked document warns of refugee funding shortfall
item.description: Resettling eligible Afghans over the next 10 years could cost more than Â£2.5bn, a leaked document says.

item.title: National Insurance: Minister refuses to deny reports of tax hike for social care
item.description: The justice secretary says social care must be properly funded but declines to "speculate" on plans.

item.title: Afghanistan: Dominic Raab says the UK has shared interest in a stable country
item.description: The foreign secretary says the UK will give Â£30m in aid to countries bordering Afghanistan.

item.title: Labour Party: Union confirms around 80 staff to take voluntary redundancy
item.description: Staff had threatened strike action if the job losses were compulsory amid financial pressures in the party.

item.title: Extinction Rebellion: Nearly 500 arrested during two weeks of action
item.description: Extinction Rebellion and its connected groups have been holding numerous protests since 23 August.

item.title: NI schools to get Â£5.5m for tracing pressures
item.description: Michelle McIlveen says schools will get Â£5.5m to tackle self-isolation and contact-tracing issues.

item.title: Pet abduction to be made new criminal offence in England
item.description: The new law will acknowledge the emotional distress pet theft can cause, ministers say.

item.title: Afghanistan: Councils prepare to offer homes to refugees
item.description: The UK has promised to resettle 20,000 Afghan refugees. Where will they live?

item.title: Austin Mitchell: Funeral of former Grimsby MP held in Bradford
item.description: Mourners gathered at Saltaire United Reformed Church for the former Labour MP's funeral.

item.title: Councils hit by bin collection delays due to driver shortage
item.description: Some 18 councils across the UK are suffering waste collection delays due to a lack of bin lorry drivers.

item.title: Social care: âWe had to sell the house right awayâ
item.description: Sharon and Edith tell the BBC how they have been impacted by the crisis in social care.

item.title: Boris Johnson outlines new health and social care tax
item.description: Boris Johnson announces a new tax to fund the NHS Covid backlog and social care reform in England.

item.title: Social care reform: BBC Political Editor questions Boris Johnson
item.description: The BBC's political editor, Laura Kuenssberg, asked the prime minister if the Conservatives are still a low tax party.

item.title: Boris Johnson asked if further tax rises are ruled out
item.description: Boris Johnson is asked for a commitment on no further tax rises in the current Parliament.

item.title: Keir Starmer on Boris Johnson's social care statement
item.description: Keir Starmer says the Conservatives can ânever again claim to be the party of low tax".

item.title: National insurance: Whatâs the new Health and Social Care tax and how will it affect me?
item.description: A new health and social care tax is being introduced, Boris Johnson has announced.

item.title: Universal credit Â£20 drop: 'I'm used to hunger pains'
item.description: Under 25s are losing the biggest percentage of their income when the payments go down in October.

item.title: Patrick Harvie and Lorna Slater: Who are the new Green ministers?
item.description: Patrick Harvie and Lorna Slater are the first Green politicians to hold ministerial office in the UK.

item.title: Universal credit: When will the Â£20 increase stop?
item.description: The government has confirmed the Â£20 boost will end in the autumn.

item.title: Lib Dem leader Ed Davey wants to target Tory heartlands
item.description: Smashing Tory dominance in the party's traditional areas is Liberal Democrats leader Ed Davey's plan. Can it work?

item.title: Levelling up: The seaside town debating what change is needed
item.description: As a report says levelling up plans must consider local views, people in Rhyl debate the changes needed.

item.title: Afghanistan: Who originally supported Trump's deal with the Taliban?
item.description: UK Defence Secretary Ben Wallace now calls it a "rotten" deal but supported it at the time.

item.title: Sent to Halifax: One town's asylum story
item.description: What life is like for asylum seekers in a Yorkshire town - and what locals think about accepting more.

item.title: Woke: Compliment or criticism, it is now fuelling the culture wars
item.description: The surprising history of a term increasingly thrown around in UK political debate.

item.title: Afghanistan: Why can't the UK hold Kabul airport without the US?
item.description: The US and UK have different timetables for the effort to evacuate people from Afghanistan

item.title: Who is Dominic Raab?
item.description: A profile of the foreign secretary, as he comes under fire for his handling of the Afghanistan crisis.

item.title: Boris Johnson feels MPs' anger during Afghanistan debate
item.description: After a year of flat debates, a full Commons proved harder for the PM to navigate, writes Jessica Parker.
